data.title: 2024 Paris Olympics: Medal winners and results
data.meta_description: The US women's basketball team capped the action off with a nail-biting win over France for an unprecedented eighth straight Olympic gold.
data.text:
From Nicole Yang in Paris: The US women‚Äôs basketball team won Olympic gold Sunday afternoon, continuing its reign of dominance on the international stage.

The game wasn‚Äôt pretty and the stats weren‚Äôt impressive, but Team USA held off a pesky French squad, 67-66, at Bercy Arena to earn an eighth consecutive gold medal.

Neither the US nor France could buy a bucket in the first half, as both teams shot under 30 percent from the field. France made 11 of its 40 attempts, while the US made 8 of 28, to head into halftime tied at 25 apiece.

France opened the second half with a 10-0 run, its largest of the game, but Team USA answered with a 8-0 run of its own. The teams then proceeded to trade baskets until the very end, as neither led by more than 4 points at any point in the fourth quarter.

Team USA, which had averaged 89.8 points per game headed into Sunday, scored its lowest point total of the Games.

Center A‚Äôja Wilson once again was Team USA‚Äôs leading scorer, with 21 points on 6 of 14 shooting (43 percent) in 33 minutes. The US finished with its worst field goal percentage of the Games, making just 34 percent of its shots.

The French certainly gave the American women their toughest game of the Olympics, as the US had won their previous five games by an average of 18.6 points. Sunday‚Äôs game featured 11 lead changes and six ties.

Cheering on Team USA courtside were Derrick White, LeBron James, and Bam Adebayo from the gold medal-winning men‚Äôs basketball team.

With Sunday‚Äôs win, the US has now won 61 straight games at the Olympics. The American women have not lost since 1992, medaling in every Olympics they‚Äôve participated in since 1976. Their run of eight straight Olympic gold medals is the longest streak in a traditional team sport. Read more here from Yang.

Medal alert! American Jennifer Valente won gold in the cycling track women‚Äôs Omnium points race.

US wins bronze: Adrian Weinberg made 16 saves in regulation and denied Vince Vigv√°ri in the penalty shootout, helping the United States beat Hungary 11-8 on Sunday for the bronze ü•â medal in men‚Äôs water polo. It‚Äôs the first medal for the US men since the team lost to Hungary in the final of the 2008 Olympics. The US also won bronze the last time Paris hosted the Summer Games in 1924.

US settles for silver in women‚Äôs volleyball: Italy beat the defending champion US team Sunday to win gold. The victory came in straight sets, 25-18, 25-20, 25-17. The Italians ended a dominant tournament having lost just one set. It‚Äôs the first medal in the sport for top-ranked Italy and sends the Americans home in disappointment after they won their first Olympic title in Tokyo.

Sifan Hassan traded elbows with Tigst Assefa with 150 meters left in the women‚Äôs marathon, then passed her along the railing to win the race for her third distance medal of the Paris Games on Sunday.

Hassan, an Ethiopian-born racer who runs for the Netherlands, finished in an Olympic record time of 2 hours, 22 minutes, 55 seconds. Assefa won silver for Ethiopia, three seconds behind, and Kenya‚Äôs Hellen Obiri took the bronze.

The Ethiopian team lodged a protest to have Hassan disqualified for obstruction, but it was rejected by the Jury of Appeal. It looked as if Assefa was blocking Hassan, who was twice impeded before they traded elbows.

Hassan raised her hands and yelled as he crossed the line, then wrapped the Dutch flag around her head as she celebrated. Wearing an orange bucket hat, she put her arm around Nepal‚Äôs Shantoshi Shrestha, whose smile was as bright as the sun pouring down on them.

Then, taking in the enormity of her win, Hassan plunged her head in her hands and appeared to weep with joy.

The 31-year-old Hassan also won bronze in the 5,000 and 10,000. By simply completing the marathon, she ran more than 62 kilometers. She now has six Olympic medals. In Tokyo, Hassan won the 5,000 and 10,000 and finished third in the 1,500.

Other medals awarded today: Denmark beat Germany for gold in men‚Äôs handball. ... Serbia beat Croatia for gold in the men‚Äôs water polo final. ... Li Wenwen of China won gold in the women‚Äôs weightlifting +81kg competition. ... Hungary‚Äôs Michelle Gulyas won gold in the women‚Äôs modern pentathlon. ... New Zealand‚Äôs Harrie Lavreysen won gold in the men‚Äôs cycling track Keirin.

From Adam Himmelsbach: France had sliced a 14-point deficit to 3 late in the fourth quarter of the men‚Äôs basketball gold medal game, and this lively crowd at Bercy Arena was surging. The French had momentum and hope, but they did not have Stephen Curry.

In a dazzling and historic shooting display, Curry drained four 3-pointers over the game‚Äôs final 2 minutes, 47 seconds, sending the US to a 98-87 win and its fifth consecutive Olympic gold medal.

Curry made 8 of 12 3-pointers in the game and finished with 24 points, following up his 36-point masterpiece in the semifinal escape against Serbia. LeBron James added 14 points and 10 assists. Victor Wembanyama had 26 points to lead France, which certainly made the host country proud with a riveting tournament performance.

Jayson Tatum, who did not play in the Americans‚Äô semifinal win over Serbia, had stints off the bench in each half and finished with 2 points on 1 of 3 shooting. Read more from Himmelsbach in Paris.

The US women‚Äôs soccer team is back on top.

Team USA edged Brazil, 1-0, Saturday afternoon to earn its fifth gold medal in program history ‚Äî and first since 2012. Forward Mallory Swanson scored the only goal, off of a perfectly placed feed from midfielder Korbin Albert in the 57th minute.

The 26-year-old Swanson, who earned her 100th cap in Saturday‚Äôs match, finishes the Olympics as Team USA‚Äôs leading goal scorer (4). Read more from Nicole Yang here.

Women‚Äôs 4x400 relay: Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Mass. native Gabby Thomas teamed up for America‚Äôs 14th gold and 34th overall medal at the track Saturday, wrapping up the Olympic action at the Stade de France with a 4.23-second runaway in the women‚Äôs 4x400 relay.

The gold medalists in the 400 hurdles and 200 meters took care of legs two and three for the United States, handing a 30-meter lead to Connecticut‚Äôs Alexis Holmes, who didn‚Äôt lose any ground.

McLaughlin-Levrone, who owns the world‚Äôs fourth-fastest time in the 400 to go with her latest world record in hurdles, ran her leg in 47.71. That was .91 seconds faster than the next fastest woman in the field, Femke Bol, who took the Netherlands to silver.

The US finished in 3 minutes, 15.27 seconds, only .1 short of the world record set by the Soviet Union in 1988.

The 34 track medals were the most for the US at a non-boycotted Games since the early 20th century, when there were more events and fewer countries. The 14 golds are the most in a non-boycotted Olympics since Bob Beamon, Tommie Smith and John Carlos led the US to 15 wins in 1968.

Men‚Äôs 4x400 relay: Rai Benjamin held off Letsile Tebogo on the anchor leg to give the United States a gold medal and an Olympic-record time in the men‚Äôs 4x400-meter relay.

Benjamin added this Olympic title to the one he claimed in the 400-meter hurdles a night earlier and prevented 200-meter champion Tebogo from giving Botswana another triumph over the Americans.

It was Tebogo, the 21-year-old sprinting sensation, who stole the spotlight ‚Äî and the gold ‚Äî from the US in the 200 on Thursday, relegating Kenny Bednarek to silver and Noah Lyles, who tested positive for COVID-19, to bronze.

The US quartet of Christopher Bailey, Vernon Norwood, Bryce Deadmon and Benjamin completed the four laps in 2 minutes, 54.43 seconds, nearly a second faster than the American 4x400 team ran at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. And Saturday‚Äôs time was just .14 seconds off the world record set by the United States in 1993.

Women‚Äôs 1,500 meters: Vermont native Elle Purrier St. Pierre got off to a strong start in the women‚Äôs 1,500 meters but faded in the back half, finishing eighth in 3:57.52, one spot behind fellow American Nikki Hiltz (3:56.38). Reigning Olympic champion Faith Kipyegon, of Kenya, left no doubt that she would defend her title, stretching her lead to more than a second by the time she reached the finish line in 3:51.29, an Olympic record. Australia‚Äôs Jessica Hull (3:52.56) won silver, just barely ahead of Great Britain‚Äôs Georgia Bell (3:52.61).

Other track medals on Saturday: Hamish Kerr of New Zealand won gold in the men‚Äôs high jump; American Shelby McEwen took silver. Kenya‚Äôs Emmanuel Wanyoni won gold in the men‚Äôs 800 meters. Japan‚Äôs Kitaguchi Haruka took gold in the women‚Äôs javelin. American Masai Russell took gold in the women‚Äôs 100m hurdles. Grant Fisher of the US snuck on the podium, winning bronze in the men‚Äôs 5,000 meters.

Ethiopian runner Tamirat Tola won the men‚Äôs marathon to end Kenya‚Äôs dominance of the race. Tola finished in an Olympic record time of 2 hours, 6 minutes and 26 seconds, with Belgium‚Äôs Bashir Abdi finishing 21 seconds behind and Benson Kipruto taking bronze for Kenya, 34 seconds back. The 32-year-old Tola looked back as he neared the line, but he was well clear and had time to soak up the applause. Two weeks ago, he entered the Olympic marathon as a substitute for injured teammate Sisay Lemma.

‚ÄúI was the reserve in the Ethiopian team, but when Sisay had injuries then I had a chance,‚Äù Tola said. ‚ÄúI was fully prepared and knew I could fulfil my dream. I am very proud, very happy.‚Äù

Eliud Kipchoge, the two-time defending champ, dropped out after 18 miles.

‚ÄúThis is my worst marathon,‚Äù said the 39-year-old Kenyan who walked for two kilometers after giving up the chase. ‚ÄúI have never done a DNF. Like a boxer, I have been knocked down, I have won, I have come second, eighth, 10th, fifth. Now I did not finish. That‚Äôs life.‚Äù Read more from John Powers.

Sabrina van der Sloot scored with .7 seconds remaining, and the Netherlands beat the United States 11-10 for the bronze medal in women‚Äôs water polo on Saturday.

It was the second women‚Äôs water polo medal for the Netherlands after it won gold at the 2008 Olympics. It also won the European championships in January.

The U.S. was looking for an unprecedented fourth consecutive gold medal going into the Olympics. Then it blew a 5-2 halftime lead in a 14-13 loss to Australia in a penalty shootout in the semis.

It struggled to score once again after Jenna Flynn‚Äôs power-play goal made it 10-7 with 4:26 left.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt handle that very well,‚Äù US coach Adam Krikorian said. ‚ÄúYeah, you know it‚Äôs a big moment and it seemed a little bit too big at times, to be honest. ... Sometimes, in these big games, it‚Äôs about who‚Äôs able to play with the courage and just be able to execute kind of towards the end of the game, and obviously they did a much better job of that.‚Äù

The US had been the only country to medal in each women‚Äôs water polo tournament at the Olympics since it started in 2000. Spain beat Australia to win gold.

Less than 40 hours after enduring one of the most gut-wrenching losses in its history, Serbia had found its way back to the the Olympic medal podium. Nikola Jokic produced the fifth triple-double in Olympic history and Serbia beat Germany 93-83 on Saturday to win the men‚Äôs basketball bronze medal at the Paris Games. Read more here.

Boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan won a gold medal in the women‚Äôs featherweight division, following Imane Khelif‚Äôs lead a day earlier with a glittering response to the intense scrutiny faced by both fighters inside the ring and around the world over misconceptions about their womanhood. Lin routed Julia Szeremeta of Poland, 5:0, in the final at Roland Garros, capping her four-fight unbeaten run through Paris by winning Taiwan‚Äôs first Olympic boxing gold medal. ‚ÄúI feel incredible,‚Äù Lin said after her fourth consecutive 5:0 win. ‚ÄúI want to thank everyone who has supported me, and thanks to my team and everyone in Taiwan. They gave me the power.‚Äù Here‚Äôs a look at the other boxing medals.

Medal alert! American Brooke Raboutou took silver ü•à in the women‚Äôs sport climbing boulder and lead final. And Nevin Harrison took silver ü•à in the women‚Äôs canoe sprint canoe single 200m final.

In breaking, American breaker Victor won bronze over Japan‚Äôs Shigekix. Canada‚Äôs Phil Wizard took gold.

Medals awarded Saturday: France beat Poland for gold in men‚Äôs volleyball. ... In weightlifting, China‚Äôs Liu Huanhua won gold in the men‚Äôs 102kg competition. Norway‚Äôs Solfrid Eila Amena Koanda won gold in the women‚Äôs 81kg competition. Georgia‚Äôs Lasha Talakhadze won gold in the men‚Äôs +102kg competition. ... New Zealand‚Äôs Lisa Carrington won the canoe sprint women‚Äôs kayak single 500m final. Czechia‚Äôs Josef Dostal won gold in the men‚Äôs kayak single 100m final. ... China‚Äôs Cao Yuan took gold in the men‚Äôs diving 10m platform. ... Norway beat France to take gold in the women‚Äôs handball final. ... China won team gold in the women‚Äôs table tennis final. ... Portugal won the men‚Äôs cycling track Madison final. ... Egypt‚Äôs Ahmed Elgendy won Africa‚Äôs first gold in the modern pentathlon. ... Here‚Äôs a rundown of the taekwondo medals.

The team of Gabby Thomas, Sha‚ÄôCarri Richardson, Melissa Jefferson, and Twanisha Terry won gold in the women‚Äôs 4x100-meter relay in the pouring rain.

Their time of 41.78 seconds beat out Great Britain (41.85) and Germany (41.97).

Richardson, the anchor, received the baton with ground to make up and closed it out in the final 100 meters. Terry, who ran the second leg, had the fastest split of the Americans, running the 100-meter distance in 9.98 seconds.

Thomas, who hails from Massachusetts, already has one gold medal after winning the 200-meter race, and in the individual 100 meters, Richardson won silver, and Jefferson won bronze.

On the men‚Äôs side, Team USA struggled on the first baton exchange and was disqualified.

The American team, a medal favorite entering the race, was without 100 meter gold medalist Noah Lyles, who has COVID-19. With the Americans out of contention after 100 meters, Canada won gold in 37.50, followed by South Africa (37.57) and Great Britain (37.61).

Watch the races here.

American sprinter Rai Benjamin convincingly beat world-record-holder Karsten Warholm and Brazil‚Äôs Alison dos Santos in the 400-meter hurdles final at the Paris Olympics on Friday.

Benjamin clocked 46.46 seconds to win gold, finishing several strides ahead of Warholm (47.06) and Dos Santos (47.26). Benjamin was able to win despite landing awkwardly coming over the eighth hurdle in a race between the three fastest men in history.

Benjamin won silver behind Warholm when the Norwegian set the world record at the Tokyo Games three years ago.

In other action, Germany‚Äôs Yemisi Ogunleye took gold in the women‚Äôs shot put. The Dominican Republic‚Äôs Marileidy Paulino took gold in the women‚Äôs 400m final. Spain‚Äôs Jordan Alejandro Diaz Fortun took gold in the men‚Äôs triple jump. Kenya‚Äôs Beatrice Chebet took gold in the women‚Äôs 10,000 meters.

It‚Äôs been smooth sailing for the US women‚Äôs basketball team throughout these Olympics.

Team USA breezed past Australia, 85-64, securing a spot in Sunday‚Äôs gold-medal game, which begins at 9:30. The US will play the winner of France vs. Belgium, which tips off Friday at 3 p.m., for a chance at its eighth-straight Olympic gold medal.

Breanna Stewart led the Americans with 16 points, 6 rebounds, and 5 assists, while Jackie Young added 14 points and 5 assists. No Australian player scored more than 11 points, as Team USA‚Äôs defense stood strong. Read more here.

Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer whose Olympics has been overshadowed by controversy drummed up by the Russian-dominated International Boxing Association, won a gold medal on Friday ‚Äî just the seventh gold for Algeria in history.

The 25-year-old from Ain Mesbah dominated Yang Liu of China, winning 5:0 in the welterweight division at Roland Garros. Read more here.

What else to know about Friday‚Äôs action ...

The Americans are thrilled to be taking home men‚Äôs volleyball hardware, outlasting Italy in a wild, back-and-forth battle for bronze on Friday. It went 25-23, 30-28 ‚Äî a sensational second set in which each country had multiple chances ‚Äî and 26-24 at a rocking South Paris Arena. The Americans had to regroup in a hurry from the heartbreak of a five-set loss to No. 1 Poland two days earlier. And this was a long time coming after they failed to even advance from group play in Tokyo three years ago. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really proud of them, it‚Äôs taken a lot of time. Time builds trust, and there‚Äôs a lot of trust in one another to go out there and perform in these moments,‚Äù coach John Speraw said. ‚ÄúThey went out and they played for their families, they played for each other. I think the amount of time that they‚Äôve spent together over the years is meaningful for all of us.‚Äù

The US men‚Äôs water polo team was bounced in the semifinal by Serbia and will play for bronze against Hungary on Sunday. That means both American teams won‚Äôt have a chance at gold after the US women lost on Thursday.

Breaking made its debut on Friday, and Japan‚Äôs b-girl Ami won gold by spinning, flipping and toprocking past a field of 16 dancers. Ami, legally named Ami Yuasa, won all three rounds in a battle against b-girl Nicka (Dominika Baneviƒç) from Lithuania to clinch the gold, wrapping up a long day of breakers putting hip-hop culture on the Olympic stage with their flow, rhythm and skill at Place de la Concorde stadium. ‚ÄúBreaking is my expression,‚Äù Yuasa said. It‚Äôs an ‚Äúexpression, an art, but I want to say that breaking also could be part of sports.‚Äù But the sport may not return for future Games ‚Äî it‚Äôs already off the list for 2028.

Spain is the first European gold medalist in men‚Äôs soccer at the Olympics for the first time in 32 years, when they won at home at Barcelona 1992. The French couldn‚Äôt bring in another medal in front of a friendly crowd at Parc de Princes.

Medal alert! US wrestling had a great day: Spencer Richard Lee (silver ü•à), Aaron Marquel Brooks (bronze ü•â), and Helen Louise Maroulis (bronze ü•â) took home some hardware Friday. Olivia Reeves won gold üèÖ in the 71kg weightlifting competition. Kristina Teachout took bronze ü•â in the women‚Äôs taekwondo 67kg contest.

Other highlights from Friday ...

Hungary‚Äôs Kristof Rasovszky won gold in the open-water marathon swimming. ... Great Britain‚Äôs Toby Roberts won gold in sport climbing boulder and lead. ... In canoe sprint, China took gold in the women‚Äôs canoe double 500m finals. New Zealand won it in the women‚Äôs kayak double 500m finals, Germany in the men‚Äôs of the same event. Czechia‚Äôs Martin Fuksa took gold in the men‚Äôs canoe single 1000m final. ... China won gold in the women‚Äôs 3m springboard diving final. ... Double Dutch! A day after their male counterparts took gold in field hockey in a shootout, the women did the same against China. ... China took the men‚Äôs team gold in table tennis. ... Italy won the cycling women‚Äôs Madison track. ... Brazil won gold in the women‚Äôs beach volleyball final.

Let Thursday serve as a reminder to never miss Sydney McLaughin-Levrone race at the Olympics ever again.

The 25-year-old took her greatness to new heights on Thursday, smashing her own world record ‚Äî already one of the most vaunted marks in track and field ‚Äî and winning a second consecutive gold medal in the 400-meter hurdles in one of the signature performances of these Games. Her time of 50.37 was 1.50 seconds ahead of fellow American and silver medalist Anna Cockrell.

McLaughlin is the first American to win back-to-back gold medals on the track since Michael Johnson in 1996 and 2000.

Grant Holloway and Daniel Roberts made it another hurdling 1-2 for the Americans, taking gold and silver in the men‚Äôs 110-meter hurdles later in the afternoon.

It was a more difficult day for Noah Lyles, who couldn‚Äôt complete the sprint double in the 200-meter final, his best event. He was upset by Botswana‚Äôs Letsile Tebogo, who became the first African gold medalist in the event and the fifth-fastest man in history over 200 meters.

After the race, Lyles, who settled for bronze, revealed that he had tested positive for COVID-19 earlier in the week. Fellow American Kenny Bednarek claimed a second consecutive Olympic silver in the event.

Pakistan‚Äôs Arshad Nadeem made history in the javelin, setting a new Olympic record with an incredible throw of 92.97 meters (305 feet) and becoming the first Olympic track medalist in Pakistan‚Äôs history.

The US made it eight medals (three gold) on the day with two more in the long jump, where Tara Davis-Woodhall took gold and Jasmine Moore took silver.

From Adam Himmelsbach: For the past month the US men‚Äôs basketball team has acknowledged the talent gap in international basketball has shrunk. Still, the Americans entered these Paris Olympics as massive favorites and had mostly rolled over their competition entering Thursday‚Äôs semifinal against Serbia.

But once the game began, it became clear this would not be like the others. The Serbians sprayed 3-pointers from all angles and relied on NBA MVP Nikola Jokic to conduct their offense.

Serbia led by as many as 17 points and still held a dangerous 13-point advantage at the start of the fourth. Then the US charged back with the finish that it needed, closing the game with a dominant 32-15 surge to secure a 95-91 win and avoid one of the biggest upsets in international basketball history.

Stephen Curry had 36 points to lead the US, and LeBron James had a triple-double with 16 points, 12 rebounds, and 10 assists. Celtics forward Jayson Tatum did not appear in the game.

The US will play France for gold on Saturday at 3:30 p.m. EDT. Read the rest here.

France, aided by old friend and former Celtics first-round pick Guerschon Yabusele, snuck past Germany to play in front of a home crowd at Bercy Arena against the Americans. Read more here.

Here are some other highlights on Thursday:

The US women‚Äôs water polo team was eliminated by Australia in the semifinals, ending its run for a fourth consecutive gold medal. Australia went 6 for 6 in a penalty shootout and goalkeeper Gabi Palm denied Maddie Musselman on the last attempt of the tiebreaker, sending the Aussies into the final. The US blew a 5-2 halftime lead in its second loss of the Paris Games and third loss at the Olympics overall since it dropped the 2008 final against the Netherlands. It went 5-0-1 in London, 6-0 in Rio de Janeiro and 6-1 in Tokyo. Read more here.

US women‚Äôs volleyball advanced past Brazil with a 3-2 win. As Brazil‚Äôs fans waved flags, chanted and sang from every corner of South Paris Arena, the US women edged their fellow world powerhouse in a five-set thriller, a compelling rematch of their Tokyo final won in straight sets by the US. That marked the Americans‚Äô first Olympic title, and now they can make it two in a row.

There was history and pride on the line when Morocco and Egypt faced off in the bronze-medal men‚Äôs soccer game, and Morocco emerged victorious with a 6-0 win.

Netherlands outlasted Germany in the men‚Äôs field hockey gold-medal game after playing to a 1-1 tie in regulation. The Dutch snuck three of their five shootout attempts past the German goalie to take gold. It‚Äôs the Netherlands‚Äô first gold in men‚Äôs hockey at the Olympics since 2000 and the third in the country‚Äôs history.

Golf: Morgane Metraux of Switzerland had eight 3s on her card on the front nine ‚Äî an 8-under 28 ‚Äî until getting slowed by the wind and a bad shot at the wrong time. She still had a 6-under 66, giving her a one-shot lead over Ruoning Yin of China at the halfway point of the women‚Äôs golf competition. Play resumes at 3 a.m. on Golf Channel.

Medal alert! American Sam Watson took bronze ü•â in the men‚Äôs speed sport climbing final.

Other medals awarded today: The Netherlands‚Äô Sharon van Rouwendaal took gold in the women‚Äôs marathon swimming, a 10km race in the Seine. ... Austria took gold in the mixed dinghy sailing final in Marseille. Italy took the mixed multihull final. And Great Britain‚Äôs Eleanor Aldridge took gold in the women‚Äôs kite final. ... China took gold in the men‚Äôs canoe sprint double 500m final. In the kayak Four 500m final, New Zealand took the women‚Äôs gold and Germany took the mens. ... China‚Äôs Xie Siyi won gold in the men‚Äôs 3m springboard diving final. ... China‚Äôs Luo Shifang took gold in the women‚Äôs 59kg weightlifting final. Take a look at all the weightlifting results here. ... In the cycling track men‚Äôs Ominum, France‚Äôs Benjamin Thomas took gold. ... Here‚Äôs a look at all the boxing results and all the taekwondo medals.

It was another huge day at Stade de France for the Americans, who picked up medals in both of the track finals on Wednesday.

First it was a thrilling run for gold üèÖ from Quincy Hall in the men‚Äôs 400-meter final, the first in the event for the American men since 2008. Hall looked out of it with 100 meters to go before reeling in the field down the home straight, edging Great Britain‚Äôs Matthew Hudson-Smith at the line in 43.40, the fifth-fastest time in history.

Hall was considered a strong medal contender, but the same couldn‚Äôt be sad for Kenneth Rooks in the 3000-meter steeplechase final. Rooks toed the line with the second-slowest personal best in the entire 16-man field but never showed it, making an extremely gutsy move to sprint away from the field down the backstretch of the final lap. With some carnage on the barriers behind him, Rooks kept the pedal down as the field thinned to three, and hung on for an incredible silver medal ü•à against the best in the world.

It was a massive nine-second personal best for Rooks, who is just the second American man to medal in the event in the last 40 years.

The US also picked up a medal in the field, with Katie Moon clearing 4.85 meters (15 feet, 11 inches) to claim silver ü•à in the women‚Äôs pole vault, her second Olympic medal after taking gold in Tokyo.

Here are some other highlights on Wednesday:

Team USA women‚Äôs basketball led by as many as 30 in the third quarter before easing off the gas late in the game to coast to a comfortable 88-74 win over Nigeria. A‚Äôja Wilson was the star for the US, registering a double-double with 20 points and 11 rebounds. Jackie Young put up 15 points, and Breanna Stewart added 13 to lead the Americans in scoring. Promise Amukamara scored 19 to lead Nigeria, but her team‚Äôs surprise run in these Games ended in the quarterfinal. See the rest of the women‚Äôs basketball scores and the rest of the schedule here.

The US men‚Äôs volleyball team was bounced out of the Olympics by Poland, 3-2. The gold-medal drought continues for the Americans, who haven‚Äôt won the Olympic tournament since 2008. But the US men‚Äôs water polo team stayed alive with its victory over Australia on Wednesday.

The US women‚Äôs cycling pursuit team of road race Olympic champion and Harvard grad Kristen Faulkner, Chloe Dygert, Jennifer Valente, and Lilly Williams held on through a ragged finish to beat New Zealand in the race for gold. The Americans led by more than a second a quarter of the way through the 4,000-meter race and stretched the lead at one point to nearly two seconds. But they began to come apart from their single-file, aerodynamic draft with about two laps to go, and they had to hang on to the finish to give their nation its first gold in the event after 12 years of close calls. Read more here.

Andy Macdonald, who is from Melrose but, at 51, competed in the skateboarding park final on Wednesday for Great Britain. He didn‚Äôt reach the medal competition, but it didn‚Äôt change his experience in Paris: ‚ÄúThe audience has been second to none,‚Äù Macdonald said, according to ESPN. ‚ÄúThere are very few things that bring the world together. Sport is one of them at the Olympics. It‚Äôs incredible. Walking around the village seeing athletes from all over the world coming together for sport is a beautiful thing.‚Äù Read more from Emma Healy.

Miles Partain and Andy Benesh could not stop the slide and the United States is leaving beach volleyball at the Olympics without a medal. Their 21-14, 21-16 defeat to Qatar‚Äôs Cherif Younousse and Ahmed Tijan on Wednesday made it the first American medal shutout since the sport joined the Summer Games in Atlanta in 1996.

Medal alert! American Hampton Morris won bronze ü•â in the men‚Äôs 61kg weightlifting competition. And Team USA‚Äôs Tom Schaar won silver ü•à in the men‚Äôs skateboarding park final.

In weightlifting, American Sarah Hildebrandt took gold üèÖ in the freestyle 50kg final.

And the US artistic swimming team, which includes North Andover‚Äôs Ruby Remati, won silver in the competition in Paris. China dominated in the absence of Russia, which had won every gold medal in artistic beginning with the 2000 Sydney Games. China finished with 996.1389 points, ahead of the Americans‚Äô 914.3421 and Spain‚Äôs 900.7319. It was the first US medal in the sport since 2004.

Other medals awarded Wednesday: Spain‚Äôs wiggliest mixed marathon race walk relay team took gold in that event. ... The Netherlands‚Äô Marit Bouwmeester won gold in the sailing women‚Äôs dinghy medal race and Australia‚Äôs Matt Wearn took it in the men‚Äôs division. ... It couldn‚Äôt have been any closer, but Noah Lyles is the fastest man in the world.

Simone Biles is golden again.

Eight years after claiming individual all-around gold in Rio and three years after a stunning withdrawal in Tokyo, Biles further cemented her place in gymnastics history with another all-around gold in Paris on Thursday.

After a minor hiccup on uneven bars saw her slip into second place behind Brazil‚Äôs Rebeca Andrade after the second rotation, Biles stuck a strong beam routine to reclaim the lead heading to the final rotation, and was in a league of her own on floor exercise to claim another dominant gold.

Andrade settled for silver, and American Suni Lee produced a brilliant floor routine to just hold off Italy‚Äôs Alice D‚ÄôAmato and Algeria‚Äôs Kaylia Nemour in a tight battle for bronze.

It‚Äôs another historic gold for Biles, who became just the third woman to win multiple individual all-around golds and the first in more than half a century, since Vƒõra ƒå√°slavsk√° went back-to-back for Czechoslovakia in 1964 and 1968.

Already the most-decorated female Olympic gymnast in American history, Biles now has nine Olympic medals to her name. Six of them are gold, which trails only Vƒõra ƒå√°slavsk√° (seven) and Larisa Latynina (nine) in Olympic history, the former of whom Biles could surpass this week with more golds in the individual apparatuses.
